question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
Suppose that \emph{A} is a matrix with singular value decomposition
$A = U\Sigma V^*$ where

\begin{align*}
U = & \begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix} \\
\Sigma = & \begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2
\end{bmatrix} \\
V = & \begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 3 & 0 & 2/\sqrt 6 \\
1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \\
1/\sqrt 3 & -1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

\textbf{(a)} Check all boxes that apply.

\emph{U} and \emph{V} are: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐,
orthogonal ☐

$\Sigma$ is: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐, orthogonal ☐

$A^*A$ and $AA^*$ are: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐,
orthogonal ☐

\emph{A} is: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐, orthogonal ☐
sols:
Since all matrices are real, \textbf{hermitian}, \textbf{real symmetric}
and \textbf{symmetric} are equivalent, and so are \textbf{unitary} and
\textbf{orthogonal}.

\subparagraph{\emph{U} and \emph{V} are: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐,
unitary ☒, orthogonal
☒}\label{u-and-v-are-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

We easily see that \emph{U} is symmetric but \emph{V} is not. Hence,
together, they are neither hermitian nor real symmetric. Since the
columns of \emph{U} and \emph{V} are orthonormal, both matrices are
unitary and orthogonal. This can be seen for \emph{U} since

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 1 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 1 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 1
\end{align*}

The corresponding vector multiplications give the same result for
\emph{V}.

\subparagraph{$\Sigma$ is: hermitian ☒, real symmetric ☒, unitary ☐,
orthogonal
☐}\label{sigma-is-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

Since $\Sigma$ is diagonal it is cleary symmetric. However, the first
and the third column vectors don't have length 1 and hence $\Sigma$ is
not unitary or orthogonal.

\subparagraph{$A^*A$ and $AA^*$ are: hermitian ☒, real symmetric ☒,
unitary ☐, orthogonal
☐}\label{aa-and-aa-are-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

Following the rules of transposition of matrix products we quickly check
that \emph{(A\textsuperscript{*}A)\textsuperscript{*} =
A\textsuperscript{*}((A\textsuperscript{*})\textsuperscript{*}) =
A\textsuperscript{*}A} and correspondingly
\emph{(AA\textsuperscript{*})\textsuperscript{*} =
((A\textsuperscript{*})\textsuperscript{*})A\textsuperscript{*} =
AA\textsuperscript{*}} so that $A^*A$ and $AA^*$ are indeed unitary and
hence also real symmetric. Next, observe that

\[\displaystyle
A^*A = (U\Sigma V^*)^*(U\Sigma V^*) = V\Sigma^2 V^{-1}\]

since, from the above, \emph{U} and \emph{V} are unitary. The equation
above however describes a diagonalization of
\emph{A\textsuperscript{*}A}, and hence the eigenvalues of
\emph{A\textsuperscript{*}A} are found on the diagonal of $\Sigma^2$,
namely 4, 1, 1/4. However, all eigenvalues of a unitary matrix must have
an absolute value of 1. Hence \emph{A\textsuperscript{*}A} is not
unitary and not orthogonal. The equivalent argument also shows that
\emph{AA\textsuperscript{*}} is not unitary and not orthogonal.

\subparagraph{\emph{A} is: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐,
orthogonal ☐}\label{a-is-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

Since the largest singular value corresponds to the matrix norm of
\emph{A} it follows that $\|A\| = 2$, while unitary and orthogonal
matrices have norm 1. To check if \emph{A} is symmetric we start by
checking the entries \emph{a\textsubscript{2,1}} and
\emph{a\textsubscript{1,2}} for equality.

\begin{align*}
A &= \begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 \\
0 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 \\
2/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix}
2/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
2/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 \\
0 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 \\
2/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix}
* & \frac2{\sqrt 6}+\frac12 & * \\
\frac2{\sqrt 6} & * & * \\
{}* & * & *
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

We see that \emph{a\textsubscript{2,1} ≠ a\textsubscript{1,2}} and hence
\emph{A} is not hermitian or real symmetric.

\_\_NOTOC\_\_
hints:
A matrix \emph{M} is called

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \textbf{hermitian} if $M = \overline{M^T}$
\item
  \textbf{real symmetric} if all entries of \emph{M} are real and
  \emph{M = M\textsuperscript{T}}.
\item
  \textbf{unitary} if \emph{MM\textsuperscript{*} =
  M\textsuperscript{*}M = I}, where $M^* = \overline{M^T}$.
\item
  \textbf{orthogonal} if \emph{MM\textsuperscript{T} =
  M\textsuperscript{T}M = I}.
\end{itemize}

For \textbf{real matrices} the conditions \textbf{hermitian} and
\textbf{real symmetric} are equivalent. Further, for \textbf{real
matrices} the conditions \textbf{unitary} and \textbf{orthogonal} are
equivalent.

A \textbf{square matrix} is \textbf{orthogonal} if the columns (or rows)
form an orthonormal basis.
